Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Cardiopulmonary Bypass Flow Rates on Renal Function

Participants.evidence: Thirty-six adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either high flow (2.9 l · min–1 · m–2, n = 19) or standard flow (2.4 l · min–1 · m–2, n = 17)

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if a higher-than-standard CPB flow improves renal blood flow, oxygen demand–supply relationship, and function, and reduces tubular injury.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was renal blood flow, measured by para-aminohippuric acid clearance, over 60 minutes.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was stratified by eGFR and left ventricular ejection fraction using an online tool.

Blinding.evidence: Neither patients nor clinicians were blinded.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Thirty-six adult patients undergoing cardiac surgery were randomised

Result_Outcome.evidence: High flow led to a larger increase in systemic oxygen delivery (100 [95% CI, 60 to 141] vs. 31 [1.9 to 65] ml · min–1 · m–2; P < 0.001)

Harms.evidence: No perfusion-related adverse events were reported.

Funding.evidence: Supported by Swedish State, ALF-agreement, Swedish Heart and Lung Foundation, and Gothenburg Society of Medicine.
